column1: '''Quest for the Silmaril''' was the quest of [[Beren|Beren Erchamion]] for a [[Silmaril]] from [[Morgoth]]'s [[Iron Crown]]
column2: as [[Thingol]]'s bride-price for his daughter [[Lúthien]]. He was aided in the Quest by Lúthien herself
column3: King [[Finrod]] of [[Nargothrond]] and [[Huan|Huan the Hound]] of [[Valinor]].  It was immortalized in the elvish poetic epic

column1: After Beren was brought before Thingol in [[Menegroth]]
column2: and Beren declared his love for Lúthien
column3: Thingol demanded a Silmaril from the Iron Crown of Morgoth.  In return he would allow Beren to receive Lúthien as his bride
column4: although Thingol deemed the task impossible
column5: and thought rather that Beren would fail. Beren sought the help of Finrod Felagund
column6: who owed Beren due to the service of [[Barahir]]
column7: Beren's father. Therefore with ten companions they set out
column9: and were promptly captured by [[Sauron]]. Sauron held them prisoner in Tol-in-Gaurhoth
column10: but he could not discern their identities or purpose. Therefore he sent a wolf to devour his prisoners one by one
column11: until only Finrod and Beren were left. When the wolf came for Beren
column12: an enraged Finrod fought tooth and nail with the wolf and killed it with his bare hands
column13: which cost him his own life. After some time
column14: Lúthien grew restless and approached her mother Melian for counsel. Melian told her that Beren was held captive in Sauron's fortress. Lúthien resolved to go and free him
column16: and ordered for Lúthien to be guarded in a house built for her. But Lúthien used her magic to weave a cloak of enchantment

column1: Lúthien encountered many perils along the way
column3: the wolf hound of Valinor. The wolf brought her before his masters
column4: Celegorm and Curufin. When she declared herself to them
column5: the two sons of Fëanor were filled with wonder and feigned friendship to her. But they betrayed and restrained Lúthien
column6: and she was held captive. Celegorm then intended to take Lúthien as his wife
column7: and he sent emissaries to Thingol
column8: demanding his allegiance. As Celegorm planned
column9: the allegiance of Doriath would enhance the power of the Noldor
column10: and further the war effort against Morgoth. Celegorm desired to unite all of the Elves of Middle-earth before he could attack Angband. But Huan took pity on Lúthien
column11: having liked her from their first meeting. Eventually this prompted Huan to speak for the first of three times. He gave Lúthien advice
column12: and freed her from captivity. He bore Lúthien away
column13: and humbled his pride by becoming her steed.

column1: They came at last to Tol-in-Gaurhoth
column2: and Sauron was aware of them. He sent wolf after wolf to the gate
column3: but Huan slew them one by one. Then Sauron
column5: imagined that he himself could be the one to end Huan. Sauron came forth himself in the shape of a terrible wolf
column6: and both Lúthien and Huan quailed before him. But as Sauron advanced
column7: Lúthien flung her cloak over Sauron's face
column8: and he was struck by the blinding enchantment of weariness. Huan used the opportunity to take Sauron by the throat. Sauron tried to escape by shape shifting
column9: but Huan held him down. Lúthien then demanded Sauron to yield the mastery of the tower to her
column10: less Huan should destroy his mortal form. Sauron yielded
column12: having received mastery of the tower
column13: laid waste to the fortress with her magic. The walls were destroyed and the prisons were broken. Lúthien found Beren and healed him.

column2: they were later ambushed by Celegorm and Curufin
column3: who knew of Beren's intentions to wrest a Silmaril from Morgoth. But Huan turned against them
column4: and with his aid Beren defeated the sons of Fëanor. While they fled
column5: Curufin shot an arrow at Lúthien
column6: but Beren stood in its path and was stuck in the chest. Huan chased the princes away
column7: and returned with herbs to cure Beren. With some effort
column8: Lúthien healed Beren. But Beren resolved to carry on his quest without Lúthien
column9: but she denied him this. Huan spoke for a second time
column10: advising that they were now bound together
column11: whether Beren will it or not. Therefore the two of them headed for Angband
column12: and were brought before the throne of Morgoth himself. Lúthien was undaunted by Morgoth
column13: and she offered to dance and sing for him in the manner of a minstrel. Morgoth beheld her with lust
column14: of which came a secret desire to do some unspeakable evil to Lúthien. Morgoth accepted for this reason
column15: but Lúthien sang a song of such enchantment that Morgoth and his court fell into a deep sleep.

column1: Beren then used the opportunity to cut a Silmaril from Morgoth's crown. The Silmaril did not burn him
column2: and Beren thought of going beyond his vow and retrieving all three of the Silmarils. But as he began to cut a second one loose
column4: and a shard struck Morgoth in the face. Morgoth and his court stirred
column5: and Lúthien and Beren fled for their lives. At the gate however they were ambushed by Carcharoth
column6: Morgoth's wolf. Beren tried to ward him off with the light of the Silmaril
column7: but Carcharoth desired it and bit off Beren's hand. But the Silmaril burned the wolf's innards
column9: Carcharoth fled. In his madness he passed through the Girdle of Melian into Doriath
column10: thanks to the power of the Silmaril.

column1: Beren was nursed to health once more by Lúthien
column2: and they returned to Doriath. Thingol was amazed to see Beren alive
column3: but he still disliked him for the doom he had brought on Doriath. But Beren told him of his tale
column4: and that a Silmaril was in his other hand. Thingol's mood towards Beren then changed
column5: and at last he yielded Lúthien to him. Eventually Carcharoth was discovered by Thingol's warriors
column6: and the wolf was attacked. Thingol was nearly slain
column7: but Beren saved him and was mortally wounded. Huan then fought with Carcharoth and slew him
column8: with both wolves dying. The Silmaril was cut from Carcharoth's burned flesh
column9: and Beren presented it at last to Thingol before he died. Thingol then held Beren with respect
column10: but Lúthien commanded Beren to wait for her in the Undying Lands. Lúthien passed away in grief
column11: and her spirit came to the halls of Mandos. There she sang a song of woe and lamentation
column12: and Mandos himself was moved to pity. He then summoned Beren's spirit
column13: and the two were reunited. But though Mandos pitied them
column14: Lúthien was faced with a choice; to remain in Valinor and its eternal bliss
column15: or for her and Beren to return to Middle-earth as mortals
column16: after which they would die a second death. Lúthien chose the latter
column17: and she and Beren returned to Doriath.

column1: Many rejoiced at their return. But when Melian saw her daughter again
column2: by virtue of being an Ainur
column3: she foresaw that a parting beyond the world was now due. Melian was grieved
column4: knowing that Lúthien would soon vanish forever. But the Quest was completed; Thingol had received the Silmaril

column1: The Silmaril retrieved from Morgoth's crown would bring about dramatic changes. The first change was the doom of Doriath. Unfortunately
column2: in naming the desire of the Silmaril
column3: Thingol had awoken the curse of Mandos. Just as Finrod warned Beren
column4: those who so much as name a Silmaril in desire moves a great power from slumber
column5: namely the Oath of Feanor. Before long
column6: the Sons of Fëanor sent messages demanding the return of the jewel. Melian counselled Thingol to give it up
column7: and save Doriath from its doom. But Thingol was angered by the prideful words of the messages
column8: and since the jewel had been won by the efforts of Beren and Lúthien
column9: he refused. He instructed the Dwarves of Nogrod to reconstruct the Nauglamir so that it would hold the Silmaril. But the Dwarves
column10: desiring the Silmaril and the Nauglamir for themselves
column11: slew King Thingol and tried to escape with the treasure. Most of them were slain and the Silmaril was returned to Melian. But it did little to soothe Melian
column12: and she was overcome with grief. Melian departed from Middle-earth and returned to Valinor
column13: and the enchantment which had fenced Doriath from evil vanished in her absence.

column1: This allowed for Doriath's eventual destruction by the sons of Feanor
column2: when they tried to reclaim the Silmaril from Dior. They failed however
column3: and the Silmaril was passed on to Elwing
column4: Dior's daughter. Eventually the sons of Feanor tracked her down too
column5: which led to the assault on the Mouths of Sirion. Elwing still managed to escape with the Silmaril.

column1: Though Morgoth did not count the missing Silmaril as a great loss
column2: it would soon result in his downfall. Elwing and her husband Earendil were guided to Valinor by the Silmaril
column3: and there Earendil pleaded with the Valar to forgive the sins of the Noldor and put an end to the darkness. The Valar granted his plea
column4: and the lone Silmaril was set in the sky as a star. The Valar assembled a mighty host in the War of Wrath
column5: which resulted in Morgoth's final defeat.
